intro: Viola canina subsp. arenaria, commonly known as the sand violet, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to sandy and calcareous soils in Europe. It typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, featuring heart-shaped basal leaves and violet or purple flowers with five petals. The plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small seeds, which are dispersed by wind. It thrives in open, disturbed habitats such as coastal dunes and sandy grasslands. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
